>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Camille – my apologies for the delay in responding; I was out of the office most of the day. Yes, I’m comfortable checking this for you or making the adjustments on your behalf.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Sakil – I reached out to QuickBooks Online (QBO) support for guidance regarding reordering the custom fields, and here’s the response I received:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Forms (Purchase Orders, Invoices, etc.):
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> QBO does not currently allow direct reordering of custom fields once they’ve been created.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The fields typically display in the order they were originally created.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> To change the order, you would need to delete the existing fields and recreate them in the desired sequence (e.g., create “PO Number” first, then “Item IDs,” and so on).
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Important note: deleting fields may result in the loss of any data already tied to those fields, so it’s recommended to back up or export data before making changes.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Reports:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When generating reports, you can usually customize the display order by selecting Customize Report and dragging/dropping columns into the preferred sequence.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> This applies only to the report view, not the forms themselves.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In short, QBO does not support drag-and-drop reordering of custom fields within forms or system-generated lists like purchase orders. The only workaround is to delete and recreate fields in the order you’d like as you previously suspected.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Please let me know if you’d like me to take any action in QBO on your behalf, or if it makes sense for us to schedule a quick call, as you suggested earlier, Camille.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Kind regards,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I know this situation is confusing, and I really appreciate all your help in working through it.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Right now, you have five custom fields in total:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> They are ordered by creation date. Since QuickBooks only allows API access to the first three custom fields, we currently can’t access PO Number and Item IDs - but those are the ones we need for the auto-invoicing system to work correctly.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The solution is to reorder the fields so they look like this:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I’m not sure if QuickBooks allows this kind of reordering directly, but I’m confident their support team can help. Could you please contact QuickBooks support and request that they reorder the fields as above?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> If they can’t or won’t, then the alternative would be to delete all of the existing custom fields and recreate them in the correct order. That said, an important question is what happens to existing documents (like invoices) that currently use those fields - QuickBooks support should be able to clarify this for you.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Sep 2, 2025, at 8:31 PM, Iza Nugent <izauranugent@gmail.com <mailto:izauranugent@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ﻿
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Good evening, Camille & Sakil,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Camille – my apologies for the delay in responding; I was out of the office most of the day. Yes, I’m comfortable checking this for you or making the adjustments on your behalf.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Sakil – I reached out to QuickBooks Online (QBO) support for guidance regarding reordering the custom fields, and here’s the response I received:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Forms (Purchase Orders, Invoices, etc.):
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> QBO does not currently allow direct reordering of custom fields once they’ve been created.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The fields typically display in the order they were originally created.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> To change the order, you would need to delete the existing fields and recreate them in the desired sequence (e.g., create “PO Number” first, then “Item IDs,” and so on).
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Important note: deleting fields may result in the loss of any data already tied to those fields, so it’s recommended to back up or export data before making changes.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Reports:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When generating reports, you can usually customize the display order by selecting Customize Report and dragging/dropping columns into the preferred sequence.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> This applies only to the report view, not the forms themselves.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In short, QBO does not support drag-and-drop reordering of custom fields within forms or system-generated lists like purchase orders. The only workaround is to delete and recreate fields in the order you’d like as you previously suspected.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Please let me know if you’d like me to take any action in QBO on your behalf, or if it makes sense for us to schedule a quick call, as you suggested earlier, Camille.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Kind regards,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Right now, you have five custom fields in total:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> They are ordered by creation date. Since QuickBooks only allows API access to the first three custom fields, we currently can’t access PO Number and Item IDs - but those are the ones we need for the auto-invoicing system to work correctly.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The solution is to reorder the fields so they look like this:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I’m not sure if QuickBooks allows this kind of reordering directly, but I’m confident their support team can help. Could you please contact QuickBooks support and request that they reorder the fields as above?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> If they can’t or won’t, then the alternative would be to delete all of the existing custom fields and recreate them in the correct order. That said, an important question is what happens to existing documents (like invoices) that currently use those fields - QuickBooks support should be able to clarify this for you.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?

>>>>>>>>>>>> On Sep 2, 2025, at 8:31 PM, Iza Nugent <izauranugent@gmail.com <mailto:izauranugent@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> ﻿
>>>>>>>>>>>> Good evening, Camille & Sakil,
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Camille – my apologies for the delay in responding; I was out of the office most of the day. Yes, I’m comfortable checking this for you or making the adjustments on your behalf.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Sakil – I reached out to QuickBooks Online (QBO) support for guidance regarding reordering the custom fields, and here’s the response I received:
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Forms (Purchase Orders, Invoices, etc.):
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> QBO does not currently allow direct reordering of custom fields once they’ve been created.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> The fields typically display in the order they were originally created.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> To change the order, you would need to delete the existing fields and recreate them in the desired sequence (e.g., create “PO Number” first, then “Item IDs,” and so on).
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Important note: deleting fields may result in the loss of any data already tied to those fields, so it’s recommended to back up or export data before making changes.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Reports:
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> When generating reports, you can usually customize the display order by selecting Customize Report and dragging/dropping columns into the preferred sequence.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> This applies only to the report view, not the forms themselves.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> In short, QBO does not support drag-and-drop reordering of custom fields within forms or system-generated lists like purchase orders. The only workaround is to delete and recreate fields in the order you’d like as you previously suspected.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Please let me know if you’d like me to take any action in QBO on your behalf, or if it makes sense for us to schedule a quick call, as you suggested earlier, Camille.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Kind regards,
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Aug 29, 2025, at 11:59 AM, Shahriar Sakil <sakil@crmcrew.com <mailto:sakil@crmcrew.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hey Camille,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I know this situation is confusing, and I really appreciate all your help in working through it.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Right now, you have five custom fields in total:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> They are ordered by creation date. Since QuickBooks only allows API access to the first three custom fields, we currently can’t access PO Number and Item IDs - but those are the ones we need for the auto-invoicing system to work correctly.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The solution is to reorder the fields so they look like this:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I’m not sure if QuickBooks allows this kind of reordering directly, but I’m confident their support team can help. Could you please contact QuickBooks support and request that they reorder the fields as above?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> If they can’t or won’t, then the alternative would be to delete all of the existing custom fields and recreate them in the correct order. That said, an important question is what happens to existing documents (like invoices) that currently use those fields - QuickBooks support should be able to clarify this for you.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Could you please reach out to them and check on this? Let me know if you have any queries.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I’m having some trouble with the restrictive QuickBooks policy around accessing custom fields via the API. Could you please clarify the following:

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The reason is that QuickBooks only provides API access to the first three string-based custom fields. While everything else in the auto-invoicing flow is working, I can’t automatically populate the PO Number because it likely isn’t within those first three.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I’d be happy to jump on a quick call today between 12:30 and 2:00 your time. I realize this is short notice, so if that doesn’t work, I completely understand and we can reschedule for Tuesday.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>> On Sep 2, 2025, at 8:31 PM, Iza Nugent <izauranugent@gmail.com <mailto:izauranugent@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> ﻿
>>>>>>>>>> Good evening, Camille & Sakil,
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Camille – my apologies for the delay in responding; I was out of the office most of the day. Yes, I’m comfortable checking this for you or making the adjustments on your behalf.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Sakil – I reached out to QuickBooks Online (QBO) support for guidance regarding reordering the custom fields, and here’s the response I received:
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Forms (Purchase Orders, Invoices, etc.):
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> QBO does not currently allow direct reordering of custom fields once they’ve been created.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> The fields typically display in the order they were originally created.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> To change the order, you would need to delete the existing fields and recreate them in the desired sequence (e.g., create “PO Number” first, then “Item IDs,” and so on).
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Important note: deleting fields may result in the loss of any data already tied to those fields, so it’s recommended to back up or export data before making changes.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Reports:
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> When generating reports, you can usually customize the display order by selecting Customize Report and dragging/dropping columns into the preferred sequence.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> This applies only to the report view, not the forms themselves.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> In short, QBO does not support drag-and-drop reordering of custom fields within forms or system-generated lists like purchase orders. The only workaround is to delete and recreate fields in the order you’d like as you previously suspected.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Please let me know if you’d like me to take any action in QBO on your behalf, or if it makes sense for us to schedule a quick call, as you suggested earlier, Camille.
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Kind regards,

>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Right now, you have five custom fields in total:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> They are ordered by creation date. Since QuickBooks only allows API access to the first three custom fields, we currently can’t access PO Number and Item IDs - but those are the ones we need for the auto-invoicing system to work correctly.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The solution is to reorder the fields so they look like this:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO Number
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Item IDs
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PO No.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> VENDOR CODE
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I’m not sure if QuickBooks allows this kind of reordering directly, but I’m confident their support team can help. Could you please contact QuickBooks support and request that they reorder the fields as above?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> If they can’t or won’t, then the alternative would be to delete all of the existing custom fields and recreate them in the correct order. That said, an important question is what happens to existing documents (like invoices) that currently use those fields - QuickBooks support should be able to clarify this for you.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>> ﻿
>>>>>>>> Good evening, Camille & Sakil,
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Camille – my apologies for the delay in responding; I was out of the office most of the day. Yes, I’m comfortable checking this for you or making the adjustments on your behalf.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Sakil – I reached out to QuickBooks Online (QBO) support for guidance regarding reordering the custom fields, and here’s the response I received:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Forms (Purchase Orders, Invoices, etc.):
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> QBO does not currently allow direct reordering of custom fields once they’ve been created.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> The fields typically display in the order they were originally created.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> To change the order, you would need to delete the existing fields and recreate them in the desired sequence (e.g., create “PO Number” first, then “Item IDs,” and so on).
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Important note: deleting fields may result in the loss of any data already tied to those fields, so it’s recommended to back up or export data before making changes.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Custom Fields on Reports:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> When generating reports, you can usually customize the display order by selecting Customize Report and dragging/dropping columns into the preferred sequence.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> This applies only to the report view, not the forms themselves.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> In short, QBO does not support drag-and-drop reordering of custom fields within forms or system-generated lists like purchase orders. The only workaround is to delete and recreate fields in the order you’d like as you previously suspected.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Please let me know if you’d like me to take any action in QBO on your behalf, or if it makes sense for us to schedule a quick call, as you suggested earlier, Camille.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Kind regards,
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Vendor Details
>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Thanks,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Shahriar Sakil

>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?

>>>>>>>> On Aug 28, 2025, at 8:00 AM, Shahriar Sakil <sakil@crmcrew.com <mailto:sakil@crmcrew.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Thanks,
>>>>>>>>

>>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,

>>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Thanks,
>>>>>>

>>>>> On Aug 28, 2025, at 8:00 AM, Shahriar Sakil <sakil@crmcrew.com <mailto:sakil@crmcrew.com>> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>>>> 
>>>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>>>> 
>>>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>>>> 
>>>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>>>> 
>>>>> Thanks,
>>>>> 
>>>>> Shahriar Sakil 
>>>>> Technical Lead
>>>>>  
>>>>> CRMCrew

>>> On Aug 28, 2025, at 8:00 AM, Shahriar Sakil <sakil@crmcrew.com <mailto:sakil@crmcrew.com>> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>> 
>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>> 
>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>> 
>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>> 
>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>> 
>>> Thanks,
>>> 
>>> Shahriar Sakil 
>>> Technical Lead
>>>  
>>> CRMCrew 
>>> W: www.crmcrew.com <https://www.crmcrew.com/>

>> Good morning Sakil, 
>> 
>> The invoicing process looks great! I do have a few questions though.
>> 
>> So we have recently started adding the invoice files in another column after we create them. Is there a way to somehow incorporate that into the process? 
>> 
>> Also, after the process has been completed, will the 'ready to invoice' tab change to ‘sent'? Or is that something we will need to go back and do? 
>> 
>> Thank you, 
>> —
>> Katie Hilton

>>> On Aug 28, 2025, at 8:00 AM, Shahriar Sakil <sakil@crmcrew.com <mailto:sakil@crmcrew.com>> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Hi Camille and Katie,
>>> 
>>> I've prepared a Loom recording of the automatic invoicing system to gather your feedback. You can view it here <https://www.loom.com/share/938098ed598f498c99e53eb8de9ed059?sid=2f2cdc01-b5bb-45ab-acf2-d3f09c8b01e4>.
>>> 
>>> Here's a quick overview:
>>> In addition to changing a line item's status to "ready to invoice", you'll now need to specify whether you want it as a single invoice or part of a group invoice.
>>> For partial invoicing, I've added a new column where you can enter the quantity you wish to invoice. While I can implement logic to ignore this for non-partial invoices, I highly recommend using this column for all invoices to prevent errors.
>>> The automation will run for a defined number of times a day, sweep all of the line items ready to be invoiced, and generate invoices based on the grouping status (single/group) and the invoice quantity. 
>>> 
>>> Once we've finalized this, I'll move on to packing slips. I have a few questions regarding them:
>>> When would you prefer the packing slips to be auto-generated?
>>> Does one invoice typically correspond to one shipment, and therefore one packing slip?
>>> 
>>> Your feedback on these points would be greatly appreciated.
>>> 
>>> Thanks,
>>> 
>>> Shahriar Sakil 
>>> Technical Lead
>>>  
>>> CRMCrew

>>> A: 15 London End, Beaconsfield, Buckinghamshire, HP9 2HN <https://www.google.com/maps/search/15+London+End,+Beaconsfield,+Buckinghamshire,+HP9+2HN?entry=gmail&source=g>

subject: 2nd Phase Integrations: Invoicing
body:
Good morning Sakil, 

The invoicing process looks great! I do have a few questions though.

So we have recently started adding the invoice files in another column after we create them. Is there a way to somehow incorporate that into the process? 

Also, after the process has been completed, will the 'ready to invoice' tab change to ‘sent'? Or is that something we will need to go back and do? 

Thank you, 
—
Katie Hilton
UP Aviation

1457 Merrimon Ave.
Asheville, NC 28804

Office: 828.774.5500
Email: katiehilton@upaviation.com 
_____________________________________________

subject: 4500479827 PO pull in.
body:
Hi Kyle,

We received a partial shipment for this order and need to wait so we can ship complete. We will also need to ship these standard overnight with our GPS tracker, as we have a new policy requiring that all electronics be shipped via air. In addition, any orders with a total cost over $3,000 must also ship by air.

We expect to have the order shipped out on Wednesday, 8/27. We apologize for the inconvenience. 

Thank you, 

—

Hi Sakil, 

PO# SAPO25-30883.1.2, that would mean line items 1 and 2 were shipped together. 

PO# SAPO25-38435 C means that the order was shipped out all at once and is complete. So all line items on the order would be marked as shipped, and would have the same tracking number. 

Hopefully that is clear, let me know.

Thank you!
—
Katie Hilton
UP Aviation

1457 Merrimon Ave.
Asheville, NC 28804

Office: 828.774.5500
Email: katiehilton@upaviation.com

subject: Phase 2 Development Updates
body:
Hi Sakil, 

For your first question, there are 3 lines for SAPO25-25703.3 because they were shipped in separate boxes. 

The naming pattern itself stems from the purchase order line items. So for instance, SAPO25-25703.3 would mean that the third subitem on the PO SAPO25-25703 was shipped out. (This is usually correct in CRM, but I typically verify by clicking the PO file to see if they are listed in the correct order). SAPO25-25703.3 is PN: MIL-PRF-46010. 

Piece tracking number is the correct column for outbound tracking. 

To answer your last question, even though SAPO25-25703.3 was sent out in three different boxes, the 3 tracking numbers still go onto the same line on CRM. We typically would format it like this in the outbound tracking number category: "883394152765, 883394152776, 883394152787”  

Let me know if you have more questions. Thank you!
—
Katie Hilton
UP Aviation

1457 Merrimon Ave.
Asheville, NC 28804

Office: 828.774.5500
Email: katiehilton@upaviation.com 
_____________________________________________

subject: Phase 2 Development Updates
body:
HelloSakil, 

I like this look but we need to add more cells and to add the log and our C of C at the bottom, and make all of the green blue.  

So each location that we ship to should have it own editable packing slip and with the shipping address listed at the top. 
Ideally we want to simply click the sub line item, have it populate that exact info into this doc, then be able to edit and add from there. 
At the top we need a cell for Part Number, Description, Condition, QTY ordered QTY shipped, and then there can be cells below all of that info that we can add a serial number, lot/batch, date of manufacture/ expiration. 

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1kiJMoGF26tuBDBopBXv2aE0ctVU4fb1EnEH17MIVGco/edit?usp=sharing￼

subject: Import/Export Information Request
body:
Hi Steve, 

I hope this message finds you well. 

As part of our compliance and procurement requirements, we are required to maintain the following information on file for all materials we purchase. Can you please provide the following details for part number 502443:
Country of Origin (COO)

Export Control Classification Number (ECCN)

Harmonized Tariff Schedule (HTS) Code

Schedule B Code

Your prompt assistance in providing this information would be greatly appreciated. Please let us know if you require any additional details to fulfill this request.

Thank you for your support.

Best regards,

—
Katie Hilton
UP Aviation

1457 Merrimon Ave.
Asheville, NC 28804

Office: 828.774.5500

>> On Jul 23, 2025, at 3:10 PM, Bob White <Jbob@pleiger.com> wrote:
>> 
>> Katie,
>> Thank you for the inquiry below.  We do offer 3/16" x 2 x 1445" strips of Vulkollan 80A.  Can you give me a little information on how you are using it?  We sell our screen printing parts through distribution, so if it is screen printing, I would need to refer you.  If it is a different type of scraper, we can sell direct.  Pleiger is a custom molder of over 30 different formulations and the only custom molder of Vulkollan and Cellular Vulkollan Foam in the US. 
>>

subject: Faith's Calendar
body:
Here you go! 

7:30 AM – Check Mail and Scan

8:00 AM – Outbound Tracking
→ Now done by Katie

9:00 AM – Owen’s Numbers
→ Monday only
(Total sales last week, weekly COGS, expenditures, floating $, unpaid column, total A/R)

9:00 AM – Enter ACH Remittance
→ Thursday only

10:45 AM – Office Snack Order
→ Monday only

11:45 AM – Update Amex Charges
→ Monday only
(Validate COGS, supplier, payment status, “ordered” flags, tax exempt forms if needed)

12:00 PM – Update COGS Sheet (Amex cleared checks → mark “paid” column)
→ Tuesday through Friday only

1:00 PM – Enter Invoices

2:00 PM – Update COGS Sheet & CRM
(Update CRM with new COGS and invoice statuses)

2:00 PM – Investigate Open (Past Due) Invoices
→ Tuesday and Thursday only

—
Katie Hilton
UP Aviation

1457 Merrimon Ave.
Asheville, NC 28804

Office: 828.774.5500
Email: katiehilton@upaviation.com

subject: Dexter Mag. Orders
body:
Good Morning Camille, 

It looks like we have a few orders in the same situation with Dexter that I mentioned yesterday. 

"Please be advised that due to updated Chinese export-controlled requirements, there has been a delay in shipping your order.
 
We are experiencing material delays related to a new export requirement mandated to our Chinese vendors from their government, with anticipated delays up to 3-4 months or longer.
 
We do not keep inventory, finished goods nor raw material on hand in most instances, so despite the timing of past Purchase orders, some going back to 2024, the impact remains.
 
Currently, we can’t provide dates and will keep you updated when more information becomes available.
 
I apologize for the delay and any inconvenience this may cause.” - Sonya Herman 

 This has been said for the following PO’s:
APPO25-03192
4500030747

Best, 
Katie Hilton
UP Aviation
1457 Merrimon Ave. 
Asheville, NC 28804
